official-title.#text:
To encourage States to require the installation of residential carbon monoxide detectors in homes,
			 and for other purposes.

cosponsor.#tail: ) introduced the following bill; which was referred to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text: Nicholas and Zachary Burt Memorial Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Prevention Act of 2014
{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.@value: Nicholas and Zachary Burt Memorial Carbon Monoxide Poisoning Prevention Act of 2014

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

Carbon monoxide is a colorless, odorless gas produced by burning any fuel. Exposure to un­healthy
			 levels of carbon monoxide can lead to carbon monoxide poisoning, a serious
			 health condition that could result in death.

Unintentional carbon monoxide poisoning from motor vehicles and the abnormal operation of
			 fuel-burning appliances, such as furnaces, water heaters, portable
			 generators, and stoves, kills more than 400 people each year and sends
			 more than 20,000 to hospital emergency rooms for treatment.

Research shows that purchasing and installing carbon monoxide alarms close to the sleeping areas in
			 residential homes and other dwelling units can help avoid fatalities.

Congress should promote the purchase and installation of carbon monoxide alarms in residential
			 homes and dwelling units nationwide in order to promote the health and
			 public safety of citizens throughout the Nation.
In this Act:

term.#tail: means a device or system that—

text.#text: The term
detects carbon monoxide; and

is intended to alarm at carbon monoxide concentrations below those that could cause a loss of
			 ability to react to the dangers of carbon monoxide exposure.
The term

term.#tail: means a carbon monoxide alarm that complies with the most current version of—

text.#text: The term

the American National Standard for Single and Multiple Station Carbon Monoxide Alarms (ANSI/UL
			 2034); and
the American National Standard for Gas and Vapor Detectors and Sensors (ANSI/UL 2075).

term.#tail:
means a room or suite of rooms used for human habitation, and includes a single family residence
			 as well as each living unit of a multiple family residence (including
			 apartment buildings) and each living unit in a mixed use building.

text.#text: The term

term.#tail: means officials of the fire safety code enforcement agency of a State or local government.

text.#text: The term
The term

the Standard for the Installation of Carbon Monoxide Detection and Warning Equipment issued by the
			 National Fire Protection Association in 2012; and

any amended or similar successor standard pertaining to the proper installation of carbon monoxide
			 alarms in dwelling units.

term.#tail: has the meaning given such term in

header.#text: Grant program for carbon monoxide poisoning prevention

text.#text: Subject to the availability of appropriations authorized under
For purposes of this section, an eligible State is any State that—

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
that the State has adopted a statute or a rule,
			 regulation, or similar measure with the force and effect of law, requiring
			 compliant carbon monoxide alarms to be installed in dwelling units in
			 accordance with NFPA 720; and

text.#text: demonstrates to the satisfaction of the

text.#text: submits an application to the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: shall determine the amount of the grants awarded under this section.

text.#text: The

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall give
			 favorable consideration to an eligible State that—

text.#text: In selecting eligible States for the award of grants under this section, the

requires the installation of compliant carbon monoxide alarms in new or existing educational
			 facilities, childcare facilities, health care facilities, adult dependent
			 care facilities, government buildings, restaurants, theaters, lodging
			 establishments, or dwelling units—
which has an attached garage; and

has developed a strategy to protect vulnerable populations such as children, the elderly, or
			 low-income households.
An eligible State receiving a grant under this section may use such grant—

to purchase and install compliant carbon monoxide alarms in the dwelling units of low-income
			 families or elderly persons, facilities that commonly serve children or
			 the elderly, including childcare facilities, public schools, and senior
			 centers, or student dwelling units owned by public universities;

for the development and dissemination of training materials, instructors, and any other costs
			 related to the training sessions authorized by this subsection; and

to educate the public about the risk associated with carbon monoxide as a poison and the importance
			 of proper carbon monoxide alarm use.
